title: I Hear Worse When I Wear Two Hearing Aids
chief_complaint: I am finding it increasingly difficult to hear in noisy environments with my hearing aids. The words sound 'jumbled' when multiple people speak. I actually find that I hear better in noise if I take my right hearing aid out and only use the left one.

problem_summary.onset: Gradual worsening over the last year since receiving new hearing aids.
problem_summary.course: Stable hearing thresholds, but increasing functional difficulty in noise.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral hearing loss; functional asymmetry favoring the left ear.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Stress, exhaustion from listening, withdrawal from social gatherings.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Significant difficulty in noise leading to social isolation; rejects remote microphone technology due to cosmetics.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Motivated hearing aid user but frustrated by current performance in noise.

history.present_illness: Patient returns 1 year after fitting of third pair of bilateral BTE aids. Reports limited benefit in noise and 'jumbled' speech. Discovered removing right aid helps in noise.
history.otologic_history: No history of tinnitus, vertigo, or family history of hearing loss.
history.medical_psych_history: Generally healthy; takes OTC medication for headaches.
history.prior_management: Experienced user (8 years). Currently wears bilateral BTE RIC aids with custom molds. Previously tried remote mic but rejected it for cosmetic reasons.
history.patient_goals: Improve hearing in noise without adding more devices.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral symmetrical mild to moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss, gradually falling configuration.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent word recognition in quiet bilaterally. No rollover observed.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Absent ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes at maximum stimulus levels (100 dB HL).

tests.name: Hearing Aid Verification
tests.key_findings: Hearing aids met manufacturer specs and NAL-NL2 REIG targets. Remote mic functioning correctly.

tests.name: Remote microphone listening check
tests.key_findings: Device confirmed to be working properly.

history.present_illness: Referral for Central Auditory Processing (CAP) assessment to investigate 'jumbled' speech and preference for monaural listening.
history.medical_psych_history: Screened for cognitive status (memory tests) prior to CAP testing.
history.patient_goals: Understand why two hearing aids are worse than one.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: No significant change in hearing status compared to previous assessment.

tests.name: Memory Screening
tests.key_findings: Administered Auditory Number Memory Forward (ANMF), Auditory Number Memory Backward (ANMB), Auditory Word Memory (AWM), and Auditory Sentence Memory (ASM). Results showed sufficient short-term and working memory to complete CAP testing.

tests.name: Competing Sentences (CS)
tests.key_findings: Extreme asymmetry observed. Patient unable to repeat sentences in Right ear when ignoring Left ear, but performed excellently in Left ear when ignoring Right. Suggests 'Amblyaudia' or dominant left ear.

tests.name: Two-Pair Dichotic Digits (TPDD)
tests.key_findings: High scores bilaterally with smaller asymmetry than CS test.

tests.name: Low-Pass Filtered Speech (LPFS)
tests.key_findings: Poor performance bilaterally, consistent with SNHL.

history.present_illness: Post-ARIA training assessment. Patient completed four 1-hour sessions of ARIA training over a 3-week period.

tests.name: Competing Sentences (CS)
tests.key_findings: Significant improvement in the right ear scores compared to baseline.

history.present_illness: Follow-up 1 month after completing ARIA training.
history.course: Reported mildly improved benefit when wearing both hearing aids in noisy environments and less stress/exhaustion. Continued withdrawal from some social gatherings.
history.plan: Continue monitoring amblyaudia; referral for cognitive assessment.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral symmetrical mild to moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss with excellent word recognition in quiet. However, central auditory processing evaluation reveals a diagnosis of Amblyaudia, characterized by a severe deficit in binaural integration with a marked left-ear dominance. This explains the 'binaural interference' where the patient performs worse with two hearing aids than with the left aid alone in complex listening environments.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows your ears are symmetrical, but the processing test shows your brain prefers the left ear significantly ('Amblyaudia').
This explains why you feel 'jumbled' in noise and why removing the right hearing aid sometimes helpsâ€”your brain is struggling to integrate the two signals.
We recommend a specific training program (ARIA) to help strengthen the weaker (right) side.
While you dislike the remote microphone for cosmetic reasons, it remains the most effective tool for signal-to-noise improvement if the training does not fully resolve the issue.
notes_for_actor: You are 82 and cognitively sharp, but you feel exhausted by social situations.
You are frustrated because you spent money on high-end hearing aids but hear worse than before in noise.
You are adamant about not wearing 'extra gadgets' like the remote mic around your neck.
Emphasize that the speech sounds 'jumbled' or mixed up when many people talk.
